Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Next Generation of Compact Infrared Laser based sensor for environmental monitoring (NexCILAS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Office of International Science and Engineering will support Professor Tittel and his coworkers at Rice University in this International Collaborative research program. The work will be conducted in collaboration with Professor Aurore Vicet of the University of Montpellier, France. NSF's French counterpart, Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR) will support the research of Professor Vicet and his coworkers. The consortium will work to develop optical sensor systems based on the integration of novel mid-infrared lasers, (quantum well, quantum cascade, and interband cascade) operating in the 3-4 micron wavelength region, into a sensor platform based on quartz enhanced photoacoustic spectroscopy (QEPAS) which is miniature and robust.

This integrated optical sensing platform promises significant improvements in sensitivity for detection of methane and other hydrocarbon greenhouse gases in environmentally important monitoring applications. The ability to sensitively detect atmospheric trace gases will impact understanding of atmospheric chemistry, and enable strategies for mitigation of pollution and global warming by greenhouse gas build up. The international collaboration facilitated by this project will provide the students involved with a valuable research experience and lead to a more globally aware scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of our International collaboration in Chemistry: Next generation of Compact Infrared Laser based sensors for environmental monitoring, funded by award CHE-1124677 was the development of compact sensors based on mid-infrared continuous wave, thermoelectrically cooled  and room temperature operated quantum cascade lasers and interband cascade lasers  for the detection, quantification and  monitoring  of  trace  gas  species  and  their  applications  in  environmental  and industrial process analysis.The first technique is quartz enhanced photoacoustic spectroscopy and the second technique is tunable laser absorption spectroscopy . Quartz enhanced photoacoustic spectroscopy and  tunable laser absorption spectroscopy use quantum cascade lasers and interband cascade lasers as optimum excitation sources that permit the targeting of strong fundamental rotational-vibrational transitions in the mid-infrared spectral region which are one to two orders of magnitude more intense in the mid-infrared than overtone transitions in the near infrared. Both techniques achieved detection sensitivities at the parts per billion and sub parts per billion concentration levels depending on the targeted trace gas. The merits of both quartz enhanced photoacoustic spectroscopy  and  tunable laser absorption spectroscopy include a compact, rugged sensing module, capable of wide  dynamic  range  and  immunity  to  environmental  acoustic  noise.

The current and critical challenge in science and engineering is the need to ensure sustainable global economic growth while at the same time reducing adverse effects due to global warming, and the negative impact on the environment and human health. Hence the development of our robust, compact, real time, cost effective, sensitive and selective instrumentation that can monitor changes in the chemical composition of atmospheric gases, in particular greenhouse gases over extended periods of time was the outcome of the research and development funded by the NSF NexCILAS project.
